discussion.content: It's A and B. Need a route in the subnet of the instance to the on premise networ k with gateway DRG and OUTGRESS (because the ping initiates in de VCN, not on premises) rule for ICMP

It's C and D. 

FastConnect virtual circuit is UP, but no traffic is passing through
Check these items:

VCN security lists: Ensure you've set up the VCN security lists to allow the desired traffic (both ingress and egress rules). Note that the VCN's default security list does not allow ping traffic (ICMP type 8 and ICMP type 0). You must add the appropriate ingress and egress rules to allow ping traffic.
Correct routes on both ends: Verify that you have received the correct VCN routes from FastConnect and the CPE is using those routes. Likewise, verify that you are advertising the correct on-premises network routes to FastConnect and the VCN route tables use those routes.
https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Network/Troubleshoot/fastconnecttroubleshoot.htm

Here we can choose A or D, my choice is A because roue table is associated to subnet level.
And between B or C, my choice is C because a stateful ingress rule implies an egress too (and we need reply from ping command).
"ping from compute instances inside the virtual cloud network (VCN) to servers" No mention of subnet. So B & D are correct one!

A and B
C: no — customer ping starts on compute instance, so without an egress rule the ping won't go out, regardless of ingress rule. The stateful egress rule (option B) allows to traffic to go out, and then get in as rule is stateful.

D: no — the subnet doesn't necessarily use the default VCN route table, you have to modify the RT associated to the subnet in whih the instance resides, that RT may be other than default route table.
https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Network/Troubleshoot/fastconnecttroubleshoot.htm

**A,** **B**
[https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Network/Troubleshoot/fastconnecttroubleshoot.htm](https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Network/Troubleshoot/fastconnecttroubleshoot.htm)
C: no — customer ping starts on compute instance, so without an egress rule the ping won't go out, regardless of ingress rule. The stateful egress rule (option B) allows to traffic to go out, and then get in as rule is stateful.

D: no — the subnet doesn't necessarily use the default VCN route table, you have to modify the RT associated to the subnet in whih the instance resides, that RT may be other than default route table.

Note that the VCN's default security list does not allow ping traffic (ICMP type 8 and ICMP type 0). You must add the appropriate ingress and egress rules to allow ping traffic.

Correct routes on both ends: Verify that you have received the correct VCN routes from FastConnect and the CPE is using those routes. Likewise, verify that you are advertising the correct on-premises network routes to FastConnect and the VCN route tables use those routes.
https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Network/Troubleshoot/fastconnecttroubleshoot.htm

comments.content: A is right. Your subnet doesn't necessarily use the default VCN route table. A would be right in any case, D only if you didn't create any subnet-specific route table.
A is wrong. You must attach a DRG with a VCN. Correct answers B and D.

discussion.content:
B, D
A is wrong. DRG is attached to VCN not subnet. Need to update VCN route table.
C is wrong. You should not allow traffic coming from anywhere.

DRG for sure .. to connect to CPE.
And Egress for sure for allowing traffic to and fro from CPE and not from anywhere.
Hence A and B seem logical ..
It should be A and B.
B and d, c is wrong as says anywhere
It's C and D.
C and D are correct yes
C is not part of the answer because the traffic should only come from the on-premise network, not anywhere.

choices.A: Modify the route table associated with the VCN subnet in which the instance resides. Add a route to the customer's on-premises network via the Dynamic Routing Gateway (DRG).
choices.C: Modify the security list associated with the VCN subnet in which the instance resides. Add a stateful ingress rule to allow ICMP traffic from anywhere.
choices.D: Modify the default VCN route table to add a route back to the customer's on-premises network via the DRG.
choices.B: Modify the security list associated with the VCN subnet in which the instance resides. Add a stateful egress rule to allow ICMP traffic to the customer's on- premises network.

questions.question_text:
A customer has established an Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) FastConnect connection to OCI. The virtual circuit is up and routes are being advertised from the customer's end, however the customer is unable to ping from compute instances inside the virtual cloud network (VCN) to servers residing in their on-premises data center.
Which two options on OCI would remedy this situation? (Choose two.)
Which service would you use if your big data workload required shared access and NFS-based connectivity?

questions.question_text:
Your company is developing a new database application in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure. You need to test application functionality including a hardware failure scenario. Since the application is still in the development phase, you want to minimize infrastructure costs.
Which database service deployment option meets this requirement?

Your on-premises hosted application uses Oracle database server. Your database administrator must have access to the database server for managing the application. Your database server is sized for seasonal peak workloads, which results in high licensing costs. You want to move your application to Oracle Cloud
Infrastructure (OCI) to take advantage of CPU scaling options.
Which database offering on OCI would you select?

discussion.content: A is Correct, question is tricky. It needs server access and no storage scaling is needed.

ANSWER : A; Tricky one: 
If a bare metal DB system requires more compute node processing power, you can scale up (increase) the number of enabled CPU cores in the system without impacting the availability of that system.
Note

You cannot change the number of CPU cores for a virtual machine DB system in the same way. ATP (Scalling Instances); BareMetal (Scaling CPU)

I would say C - Select auto scaling to allow the system to automatically use up to three times more CPU and IO resources to meet workload demand, compared to the database operating with auto scaling disabled. The additional resources are available until you disable auto scaling by deselecting Auto Scaling. See Use Auto Scaling for more information.
A is Correct

Answer is C. Oracle Cloud
Infrastructure (OCI) to take advantage of CPU scaling options and ATP is autoscaling for CPU.

comments.content:
Ans A. 
It need "Administrator access to the database server for managing the application". But ATP doesn't provide server access.
